case_vignette: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency room complaining of left shoulder pain for several weeks. He says that the pain often worsens when he tries to sleep on his left side. Although he tried several pain medications, none of the pain medications helped. He is an amateur tennis player who practices on weekends. He denies any trauma during his practice sessions. On examination of the shoulder joint, severe tenderness was present localized to the greater tuberosity of the left shoulder joint along with biceps tendon tenderness over the bicipital groove. The range of motion was limited to the left side. An X-ray of the joint showed narrowing of the acromiohumeral space with sclerosis and spurring of the acromion. Routine blood test results are normal except for the rheumatoid factor, which is positive.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having pain in my left shoulder for several weeks, and it gets worse when I try to sleep on that side.
Is this pain constant or does it come and go?
The pain is not constant; it often worsens when I try to sleep on my left side.
Have you noticed any redness, warmth, or swelling in the affected shoulder?
No, I haven't noticed any redness, warmth, or swelling.

Do you have a history of joint pain or inflammation in other parts of your body?

**Final Diagnosis:** Shoulder bursitis (if no other joint involvement or systemic symptoms) or Rotator cuff tendinitis (if no improvement with rest and physical therapy). If symptoms persist despite treatment, consider rheumatoid arthritis or other inflammatory conditions.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of shoulder pain that has been ongoing for several weeks. The pain is exacerbated when attempting to sleep on the left side, and the patient denies any redness or swelling.
trial_1.vignette_mcq: Rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's symptoms, positive rheumatoid factor, and imaging findings are consistent with this diagnosis.
trial_1.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is Shoulder Rotator Cuff Tendinitis or Subacromial Bursitis with a possible component of calcific tendinitis based on the patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and imaging results. trial_1.summarized_mcq: Rotator cuff injury. Shoulder pain that worsens when lying on the affected side is a common symptom of rotator cuff injuries. Trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, and referred pain from the neck and back can also cause shoulder pain, but the given symptoms are most suggestive of a rotator cuff injury.
trial_1.summarized_frq: Shoulder bursitis or Rotator cuff tendinitis.

[Answer: No]

[Answer: No]

Have you taken any new medications or undergone any recent surgeries?

[Answer: No]

Final Diagnosis: Adhesive Capsulitis (Frozen Shoulder)
